medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient presented at age 16 years with nocturnal seizures and restless movements during sleep. Seizures were well-controlled initially, but multiple cVEEG admissions were required between ages 16 and 27 years due to increased seizure frequency. Seizures were characterized by head version to the left, posturing, fumbling, and lip-smacking, occurring every 10-30 minutes during stage 2 sleep, lasting 30-60 seconds each. Previous treatments were ineffective, leading to further seizures.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Medical history notable for glaucoma, resolved by age 22 years. Multiple failed trials of anticonvulsants including oxcarbazepine, lamotrigine, levetiracetam, zonisamide, valproic acid, acetazolamide, pregabalin, phenytoin, clorazepate, and lacosamide. Previous implantation of a vagal nerve stimulator without success.
medical_history.family_history: The patient's brother and a paternal cousin had similar nocturnal seizures since their early teens. Family history suggests a hereditary condition.
medical_history.social_history: The patient had never smoked, used alcohol, or illicit drugs. Her brother started smoking at age 17 and was previously on anticonvulsants but believed himself to be seizure-free. The father was a heavy smoker but asymptomatic. The patient completed college without difficulty.
